Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a mass spectrometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor Viktor Nemykin from University of Minnesota Duluth and colleagues Steven Berry, Venkatram Mereddy and Viktor Zhdankin will acquire a microTOFMS with electrospray inionization (ESI), atmospheric pressure chemical ionization (APCI), and atmospheric-pressure photoionization (APPI) capabilities. In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species embedded in complex matrices. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized into the parent ion and its fragment ions and their masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows detection and determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. As a primarily undergraduate institution, the faculty at the University of Minnesota Duluth embraces undergraduate research experiences as one of the most important outcomes of their research activities. The proposed instrument will directly impact the research experiences of a large number of undergraduate and master students within the three-year project period, and many more in years to come. The instrument will be used in classroom and research activities.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) determining structure, stability, and reactivity of small organic, inorganic, and organometallic synthetic molecules; and (b) investigating potentially bioactive compounds prepared using organic synthesis approaches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The new Bruker Q-TOF III mass-spectrometer brought the research and teaching experience for UMD students and faculty to the next level. The instrument fully alleviated the need to travel to the other MS facilities, the nearest one being a three hour drive away. Research productivity was improved dramatically due to its close proximity, ease of sample transport, and ease of instrument access. Students themselves were allowed to run the instrument, rather than a technician, which is common at larger facilities. In the lecture classes and in the research laboratory, the instrument therefore allowed for valuable hands-on use by students, providing them with vital training for future careers.       

The new instrument was used in two graduate level classes over the grant period: Applications of Spectroscopy and Advanced Inorganic Chemistry I.  In the case of the Advanced Inorganic Chemistry I class, all students underwent a hands-on training experience with the instrument. These students were then qualified to use the instrument for research purposes.

In addition, students and individuals who were not able to take the classes, including undergraduate students, post-doctorate students, or research assistants, were trained in person. Following completion of training and a checkout procedure, these individuals were then allowed to use the instrument for research purposes. In addition, users were trained on proper calibration techniques, data acquisition, data processing, interpreting data, and reporting results. Methods development procedures were discussed at length. The sources were changed about once a month and instrument users obtained data in both the APCI and ESI modes.  

Many of the students collected data for their Master's Thesis, and some of the undergraduates used data in their undergraduate seminar presentations. Faculty from other departments and units used the instrument for their research as well. In addition to the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry’s use of the instrument, students and faculty from UMD Pharmacy, Integrated Biosciences, Civil Engineering, and Drug Discovery units tested samples on the MS. Finally, a faculty member from a neighboring college, who collaborates with a co-PI, analyzed some small molecule samples on the instrument. More than 20 peer reviewed papers with acknowledgement for this MRI grant were published during this grant reporting period.

Maintenance and care of the instrument continues to be provided by the UMD Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry. The instrument will therefore continue to support state-of-the-art research and teaching opportunities for students and faculty.
